stages.title: 1 | The Carved Vessel
stages.blurb: The Warka Vase is one of the earliest examples of narrative relief sculpture, crafted from alabaster and intricately carved with scenes depicting religious rituals and offerings.

content_blocks.title: Material and Crafting
content_blocks.text: The Warka Vase was carved from alabaster, a soft stone that allowed artisans to etch complex images. Alabaster was prized for its smooth texture and ability to capture fine details.

content_blocks.title: Relief Carving Technique
content_blocks.text: Artisans used chisels to create the vaseâ€™s detailed carvings. They worked carefully, ensuring that each figure stood out against the smooth background.

content_blocks.title: Vessel's Religious Significance
content_blocks.text: The scenes on the vase depict processions and offerings, highlighting its importance in religious rituals. It was likely used in temple ceremonies.

stages.title: 2 | The Processions
stages.blurb: The carvings on the Warka Vase are divided into bands that tell a story, showing processions of people bringing offerings to the gods in a sacred ritual.

content_blocks.title: Upper Band - The Gods
content_blocks.text: At the top of the vase, deities are depicted receiving offerings. These figures symbolize the divine presence, with their majestic stances dominating the scene.

content_blocks.title: Middle Band - The Procession
content_blocks.text: In the middle band, humans bring offerings to the gods. This scene represents the connection between mortals and the divine, a key theme in ancient Mesopotamian culture.

content_blocks.title: Lower Band - Fertility and Agriculture
content_blocks.text: The bottom of the vase shows flowing water and fertile land, symbols of life and abundance. These carvings reflect the importance of agriculture in religious rites.

stages.title: 3 | The Vase's Legacy
stages.blurb: The Warka Vase is not only a masterpiece of art but a glimpse into the religious life of ancient Mesopotamia, providing valuable insights into early civilization.

content_blocks.title: Significance in History
content_blocks.text: As one of the oldest surviving examples of narrative art, the Warka Vase gives us insight into the spiritual and daily lives of ancient Mesopotamians.

content_blocks.title: Discovery and Preservation
content_blocks.text: The vase was discovered in the ruins of Uruk, a city in modern-day Iraq. Despite being thousands of years old, it retains much of its original detail.

content_blocks.title: A Link to Ancient Beliefs
content_blocks.text: The carvings on the vase serve as a testament to the ancient Mesopotamian belief in the connection between the natural world and divine forces.
